Enhanced soot combustion over partially substituted hydrotalcite-drived mixed oxide catalysts CoMgAlLaO Fangfang Dai a Yuxia Zhang a Ming Meng a ⁎ Jing Zhang b Lirong Zheng b Tiandou Hu b a Collaborative Innovation Center for Chemical Science and Engineering (Tianjin), Tianjin Key Laboratory of Applied Catalysis Science and Engineering, School of Chemical Engineering and Technology, Tianjin University, Tianjin 300072, PR China Collaborative Innovation Center for Chemical Science and Engineering (Tianjin), Tianjin Key Laboratory of Applied Catalysis Science and Engineering, School of Chemical Engineering and Technology, Tianjin University Tianjin 300072 PR China b Institute of High Energy Physics, Chinese Academy of Sciences, Beijing 100049, PR China Institute of High Energy Physics, Chinese Academy of Sciences Beijing 100049 PR China ⁎ Corresponding author. Tel.: +86 022 2789 2275; fax: +86 022 2789 2275. Graphical abstract A series of hydrotalcite-derived multicomponent oxide catalysts Co2.5Mg0.5Al1–x%La x%O (denoted as CMALa x , x =0, 5, 8, 10 or 15) with different La contents were synthesized by co-precipitation, and employed for catalytic soot combustion and NO x storage at lean condition. It is found that the La-substituted catalysts are more active than the one without La for soot combustion and NO x storage. Among all the catalysts CMALa x , CMALa10 (x =10) exhibits the highest catalytic performance, showing the largest NO x storage capacity (300μmol/g) and the lowest temperature for the maximal soot oxidation rate (T m =388°C). The results of H2-TPR and O2-TPD indicate that the La-substitution can enhance the redox properties and increase the amount of surface lattice oxygen species of the catalysts. The results of soot combustion kinetics show that the apparent activation energy of CMALa10 is the lowest (92.75kJ/mol). Based upon the catalytic performance and in situ DRIFTS characterization, a nitrate and/or NO2 enhanced soot combustion mechanism over CMALa10 was proposed. It is revealed that at low temperature the stored nitrate can directly promote soot ignition, while at high temperature the NO2 species arising from NO oxidation or nitrate decomposition act as the main active species for soot combustion. Keywords Hydrotalcite Lanthanum Soot combustion Nitrate Mechanism 1 Introduction It is well known that diesel engines possess higher fuel efficiency, larger output power and better durability than traditional gasoline engines. So, many kinds of vehicles including light and heavy trucks, ships and cars have been equipped with diesel engines. However, the main pollutants in diesel exhausts namely nitrogen oxides (NO x ) and soot particulates materials (PM) are very harmful or poisonous to human and environment. Therefore, novel after-treatment technologies for diesel exhaust elimination are highly desired. The inner purification techniques based upon the modification of diesel engine structures can only decrease the amounts of these pollutants to a very limited extent, so, the outer after-treatment purification techniques such as filtration trapping, catalytic soot combustion and NO x reduction are still required. Nowadays, diesel particulate filters (DPFs) have been widely used for soot removal, which can trap most soot particulates efficiently [1,2]. However, after used for some time the pressure drop before and after the DPFs will dramatically increase, so it is necessary to periodically regenerate the DPFs by burning the trapped soot. When highly active oxidation catalysts are coated on the DPFs, the trapped soot can be in situ removed through a continuous catalytic combustion process, which is more economic and more convenient [3]. Meanwhile, the oxidation catalysts can also oxidize the NO to NO2, enhancing the simultaneous removal of NO x and soot. In addition, it is reported that the NO2 can be further oxidized and stored as nitrate species in the catalysts, participating the soot oxidation [4]. Although the decomposition of nitrates often requires high temperature, they can react with soot at much lower temperature [5–7]. Therefore, the formation of nitrate species should be favorable to soot combustion. So far, many kinds of metal oxide catalysts have been investigated and employed for soot combustion [8–11]. Among them, Co-based oxide catalysts such as perovskites and hydrotalcite-derived oxides have exhibited excellent catalytic oxidation performance [12–15], especially the hydrotalcite-derived Co oxide catalysts which possess high specific surface area and high dispersion of active phases [16–18]. Nevertheless, the thermal stability of hydrotalcite-derived Co oxide catalysts is much lower than that of others such as Co-based perovskites. It is known that soot combustion is a strong exothermic reaction, possibly making the catalysts sintered. So, the improvement of the thermal stability of hydrotalcite-derived Co oxide catalysts is still necessary. It has been reported that the hydrotalcite-derived CoMgAlO catalysts are rather efficient for soot combustion and NO x storage since the mixed oxides derived from hydrotalcites often exhibit large specific surface area, strong basicity and good reducibility [19,20]. To further increase both the catalytic performance and the thermal stability of them, in present work, lanthanum known as an effective thermal stabilizer is selected and doped into the hydrotalcite-based CoMgAlO catalyst to replace some of the aluminum. By using co-precipitation method, a series of hydrotalcite-derived catalysts Co2.5Mg0.5Al1–x%La x%O with different La contents were synthesized. According to the results of catalytic performance and many kinds of characterizations, the content of La was optimized; meanwhile, the enhancement effect of La substitution on the CoMgAlO catalyst was also investigated from the views of bulk/surface/coordination structures, redox properties, oxygen activation capability and NO x adsorption/storage capacity. By using in-situ DRIFTS technique the NO x storage pathway and the nitrate-assisted soot combustion mechanism were revealed. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst preparation A series of Co2.5Mg0.5Al1–x%La x% hydrotalcite-like compounds (HTlc) were prepared using co-precipitation method at constant pH (10±0.5) under vigorous mechanical stirring [21]. The molar ratio of Co:Mg:Al:La is 2.5:0.5:(1–x%):x%, and x was set at 0, 5, 8, 10 or 15. Briefly, the metal nitrates (50mL) consisting of Co(NO3)2·6H2O, Mg(NO3)2·6H2O, Al(NO3)3·9H2O and La(NO3)3·6H2O were dissolved into distilled water to form a mixed solution. Meanwhile, another mixed basic solution (50mL) containing NaOH and Na2CO3 was also prepared with [OH−]=2.0M and [CO3 2−]=1.0M. The obtained precipitates were kept in suspension at 70°C for 12h, then filtered and thoroughly washed with distilled water. After dried at 120°C overnight, the precursors of HTlc were obtained and then calcined at 600°C for 4h to get the desired catalysts Co2.5Mg0.5Al1–x%La x% which are denoted as CMALa x . 2.2 Catalyst characterization The crystal structures for the precursors and calcined catalysts were recorded on a Rigaku D/Max-2500 X-Ray diffractometer operating at 200mA and 40kV using Cu Kα1 as radiation source (λ =0.15406nm). The scanning range of 2θ is from 6 to 80° with a step size of 0.02°. Specific surface area was measured by nitrogen adsorption/desorption at 77K using a Quantachrome Quadrasorb SI instrument. The samples were degassed at 300°C for 3h prior to the adsorption experiments. The specific surface area (SSA) was determined by BET method in 0–0.3 partial pressure range. Temperature-programmed reduction (H2-TPR) measurements were performed on the TP-5079 TPDRO setup (Tianjin Xianquan Instrument Company) equipped with a thermal conductivity detector (TCD). Before detection by the TCD, the gas was purified by a trap containing CaO+NaOH materials in order to remove H2O and CO2. A heating rate of 10°C/min and a gas (8% H2 in N2) flow rate of 30mL/min were used. Temperature-programmed desorption (O2-TPD) measurements were conducted on a TPDRO 1100 apparatus supplied by Thermo-Finnigan Company. During the test, 100mg of each sample were pre-heated in pure O2 from room temperature to 500°C and held for 30min. After cooling to room temperature, the sample was heated from room temperature to 900°C at a heating rate of 10°C/min in pure helium. Extended X-ray absorption fine structure (EXAFS) measurements were carried out on the XAFS station of 1W1B beamline of Beijing Synchrotron Radiation Facility (SSRF) operating at about 150mA and 3.5GeV. The absorption spectra of Co K-edge of the samples and the reference compounds were recorded at room temperature in transmission mode. A Si (111) double crystal monochromator was used to reduce the harmonic content of the monochrome beam. The back-subtracted EXAFS function was converted into k space and weighted by k 3 in order to compensate for the diminishing amplitude due to the decay of the photoelectron wave. The Fourier transforming of the k 3-weighted EXAFS data was performed in the range of k =3 to 13Å−1 using a Hanning window function. In-situ DRIFTS experiments were performed on a Nicolet Nexus spectrometer supplied by Thermo Nicolet Company, which was equipped with a MCT detector and a heating chamber allowing the temperature increased to 600°C. The DRIFT spectra were recorded against a background spectrum of the sample purified just prior to introducing NO x . In each run, about 20mg powder sample was first pretreated under 20vol.% O2/N2 (30mL/min) at 200°C for 30min and then exposed to a flow of 500ppm NO+5vol.% O2 balanced by N2 (30mL/min). All spectra were collected on 16 scans at a resolution of 4cm−1. 2.3 Activity measurement For soot combustion, the catalytic activity of the prepared samples was evaluated by a Perkin-Elmer Diamond TG/DTA instrument using Degussa Printex-U as the model soot. The soot was mixed with the catalyst in a mortar for about 5min to obtain a tight contact with a weight ratio of 1:9. Then, the mixture (about 8mg) was loaded to the sample chamber and heated from room temperature to 600°C at a rate of 10°C/min in different atmospheres: (i) 600ppm NO+10vol.% O2 balanced by N2 and (ii) synthetic air (20vol.% O2 +80vol.% N2). The characteristic temperatures corresponding to the maximal soot combustion rate (denoted as T m ) in the DTG profiles were used to evaluate the performance of different catalysts. The activation energy (Ea) for soot combustion over the catalysts was measured by using the reported Ozawa method [22]. According to this method, the activation energy can be calculated by the following equation: ln B = − 0.4567 E a R 1 T + C here C is a constant and B is the heating rate. In this work, soot combustion tests were carried out at three different heating rates (B 1 =5°C/min, B 2 =10°C/min, B 3 =15°C/min). Then each pair of ln B and 1/T of these data was used for plotting. From the equation, Ea could be calculated by the slope of the plotted line. For NO x storage, experiments were carried out in a continuous fixed-bed reactor under atmospheric pressure, using the gas mixture of 600ppm NO, 10vol.% O2 and balanced N2 as adsorbates. The granular catalyst (40–60mesh, 0.3mL) was fixed in a quartz tube (i.d.=8mm) by packing quartz wool at the end of the bed, and heated from 100 to 600°C at a rate of 10°C/min. The mixture gas passed through the catalyst bed at a flow rate of 150mL/min. An on-line chemiluminescence NO–NO2–NO x analyzer (Model 42i-HL, Thermo Scientific) was used to measure the concentrations of NO, NO2 and NO x in the outlet gas. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Characterization of the catalysts 3.1.1 XRD and EXAFS The XRD patterns of the catalyst precursors are displayed in Fig. 1 , which indicates that the hydrotalcite (JPCDS 51-0045) structures were successfully synthesized and no other phases were detected. The partial substitution of Al3+ by La3+ did not destroy the layer structures of the hydrotalcite. However, the diffraction peaks of hydrotalcites become weaker after La substitution, especially for the samples containing relatively high contents of La (x ≥10), which suggests the decrease in crystallization degree of hydrotalcite phases. Fig. 2 shows the XRD patterns of the catalysts calcined at 600°C. It is found that the peaks for hydrotalcite phases have totally disappeared after calcination, forming new phases such as cubic spinels and trace LaCoO3 perovskite based upon the observed diffraction peaks. Since many diffraction peaks for the spinels of Co3O4 (JPCDS 43-1003) and Co2AlO4 (JPCDS 38-0814) are very close or overlapped with each other, it is very hard to distinguish these phases just by XRD method. However, after careful comparison, the intensity of the three strongest lines of XRD patterns of the catalysts is more similar to that of Co3O4 spinel. Meanwhile, EXAFS characterization was performed to make a further determination of Co phases. The radial structure functions (RSFs) of Co K-edge of the catalysts and the reference compounds are displayed in Fig. 3 . It is easily found that the RSFs of the catalysts are similar to those of pure Co3O4 and Co2AlO4. The similarity of the RSFs for Co2AlO4 and Co3O4 is due to their similar coordination structures. In the crystal structure of Co3O4 Co atoms exist in heterogeneous coordination environments; one Co atom is in tetrahedral coordination environment, while the other two are in octahedral coordination environment. For Co2AlO4, there are only two Co atoms in the molecule, one is in tetrahedral coordination environment, and the other is in octahedral coordination environment [23]. Combined with the XRD analysis, it can be concluded that the Co in the catalysts mainly exists as Co3O4. Averagely, in spinel Co3O4 each Co atom coordinates with 5.3 O at 1.91Å (first shell), with 4 Co at 2.85Å (second shell) and with 8 Co at 3.36Å (third shell), respectively [24]. In the RSFs of the catalysts (Fig. 3) the first three peaks appearing at 1.44Å, 2.42Å and 2.95Å (not corrected by phase scattering shift) can be attributed to the above three coordination shells, respectively. Based upon the line broadening of (311) plane (2θ =36.9°) in Fig. 2, the sizes of Co3O4 crystallites in different catalysts are calculated by using Scherrer equation, as listed in Table 1 . It can be seen that the size of Co3O4 crystallites decreases after La substitution. The sample containing 10% La possesses the smallest Co3O4 crystallite size (∼7.6nm). The altering tendency of BET surface area and Co3O4 crystallite size for the catalysts with different La contents is totally the same, as seen in Table 1. In a summary, the presence of appropriate amounts of La in CoMgAlO hydrotalcite-derived catalysts can efficiently inhibit the sintering of catalysts during calcination process. 3.1.2 H2-TPR and O2-TPD H2-TPR technique can be employed to characterize the reducibility and mobility of oxygen species in the catalysts [14]. As shown in Fig. 4 , the H2-TPR profiles of all the catalysts are similar to each other, showing two main reduction peaks, which may correspond to a two-step reduction process (Co3+ →Co2+ →Co0) of Co3O4; the reduction peaks centered around 377°C are associated with the reduction of Co3+ to Co2+, while the high-temperature peaks above 700°C are attributed to the reduction of Co2+ to Co0 [19,25]. Such assignment is strongly supported by the appropriate area ratio of 1/3 for the first peak to the second one [26], as listed in Table 1. In addition, the analysis of H2-TPR results is also in good agreement with EXAFS results. In Fig. 4, the trace shoulder peaks appearing in the region of 130–260°C could be assigned to the reduction of surface adsorbed oxygen species [27]. By comparing the reduction profiles of different catalysts, it can still be found that the first reduction peaks (357°C) for CMALa8 and CMALa10 appear at a little lower temperature, suggesting the better reducibility and higher oxygen mobility of these two catalysts. Temperature-programmed desorption of oxygen (O2-TPD) measurement was also carried out to investigate the mobility and amounts of oxygen species in the catalysts, especially the surface oxygen species, the results of which are shown in Fig. 5 . Three oxygen desorption peaks (α, β and γ) were clearly observed for each catalyst. The peak α appearing at low temperature region (around 200°C) corresponds to the desorption of surface chemisorbed oxygen species. The peak β appearing in the middle temperature region between 400 and 650°C is attributed to the desorption of surface lattice oxygen [27–29]. By careful observation, it is seen that the peak β for all samples starts from almost the same temperature (∼410°C), but ends at different temperatures, indicating the different amounts of surface oxygen species over CMALa x catalysts. The sample CMALa10 with the largest peak β should possess the largest amount of surface oxygen species. As to the peak γ which appears at very high temperature region (around 820°C), it should be resulted from the thermal decomposition of bulk Co3O4 to CoO [27]. Taking into account that the soot combustion over these catalysts mainly takes place at middle temperature region (330–500°C, see next section), it is deduced that the peak β-related surface oxygen species should be the main active oxygen species which may play a crucial role for soot oxidation because the bulk lattice oxygen corresponding to peak γ is too stable, and the very small amounts of surface chemisorbed oxygen species corresponding to peak α have already desorbed at reaction temperatures. In a summary, the La-substitution can increase the amount of surface oxygen species in CMALa x catalysts, especially for the catalyst CMALa10. 3.2 Soot combustion over CMALa x catalysts Fig. 6 shows the results of soot combustion activity of the catalysts in the atmosphere containing NO. It is seen that the introduction of La remarkably enhances the soot combustion over these catalysts, evidenced by the obvious decrease of the characteristic temperature T m corresponding to the maximal soot combustion rate. According to T m , the activity of these catalysts is arranged in the order of CMALa10 >CMALa8 ≈CMALa15 >CMALa5 >CMALa0. The catalyst CMALa10 shows the lowest T m (388°C), which is ∼56°C lower than that for CMALa0. For comparison, the soot combustion activity of these catalysts in air was also evaluated, the results of which are shown in Fig. 7 . The activity order is identical to that in the NO x -containing atmosphere. However, over the same catalyst the T m is much higher than that in NO x -containing atmosphere, suggesting that the presence of NO does enhance the soot combustion. The best catalytic performance of CMALa10 could be elucidated from the following three aspects: (1) this catalyst has the largest specific surface area and smallest crystallite size of Co3O4; (2) this catalyst possesses the best reducibility; (3) this catalyst has the largest amount of surface lattice oxygen, which is the main active oxygen species for soot combustion. In a word, the La substitution is really efficient for the improvement of the catalytic performance for soot combustion of the hydrotalcite-derived CMALa x catalysts; the optimal substitution amount of La is x =10%. In order to better understand the promotional effect of La in the substituted catalysts CMALa x , a series of kinetic experiments were performed and the apparent activation energy for soot oxidation was calculated, as listed in Table 1. It is obvious that the apparent activation energy of catalytic soot combustion is much lower than that of non-catalytic soot combustion (Ea =139.7kJ/mol). After addition of La, the activation energy further decreases to some extent. The catalyst CMALa10 with the highest soot combustion activity possesses the lowest activation energy (Ea =92.75kJ/mol). 3.3 NO x storage over the catalysts To characterize the function of NO existing in the atmosphere during soot combustion, in-situ DRIFTS technique was employed to identify the NO x -stored species over CMALa10 under NO x /O2 atmosphere. As shown in Fig. 8 , in low-temperature region (≤200°C), only one small absorption band at 1220cm−1 was identified, which is attributed to bridged bidentate nitrite species [30]. With the temperature increasing to 300°C, the band at 1220cm−1 disappeared but a new band at ∼1293cm−1 corresponding to chelating bidentate nitrate species [30,31] appeared, suggesting that nitrite species have transformed to nitrate species. Fig. 9 presents the profiles of temperature-programmed NO x adsorption/storage and desorption over different samples. The points below and above the dot line (NO concentration in feed stream) mean the occurrence of NO x adsorption/storage and NO x desorption, respectively. Based on Fig. 9, the NO x storage capacities (NSCs) of different catalysts were calculated and listed in Table 1. It is found that the La-substituted catalysts exhibit much larger NO x storage capacities than the La-free sample, especially the sample CMALa10 which shows the maximal NSC of 300μmol/g. Generally, nitrites and nitrates are arising from the oxidation of NO or NO2 by surface oxygen species [32,33]. The sample CMALa10 has the largest BET surface area, the best reducibility and the largest amount of surface lattice oxygen, which determine its highest NO x storage capacity and best oxidation performance for soot combustion. Fig. 10(a) and (b) present the DTG profiles of soot combustion over CMALa10 in the presence or absence of NO x as well as the NO x concentration curves during temperature-programmed heating on CMALa10 or CMALa10/soot in NO x -containing atmosphere, respectively. By comparing the DTG profiles in Fig. 10(a), it is found that the presence of NO x has greatly enhanced the soot combustion, as indicated by the obvious decrease of T m . Meanwhile, the ignition temperature (Ti) of soot combustion in NO x -containing atmosphere is also remarkably decreased from ∼340°C to 300°C. At this temperature (Ti), the NO x concentration from reactor outlet is much lower than that at reactor inlet (dash line) as seen in Fig. 10(b), which suggests that most of the NO x is still being stored as nitrates on the catalyst, as confirmed by in situ DRIFTS results (Fig. 8). So, it is natural to assume that in the NO x -containing atmosphere the soot combustion over CMALa10 may be enhanced by the as-formed nitrate species. On one hand, at relatively low temperature (300–340°C), the stored nitrate species are thermo-stable, which have not decomposed into nitrogen oxides, making the NO x concentration at reactor outlet lower than that at reactor inlet; the enhanced ignition of soot combustion may be resulted from the direct reaction between nitrate species and soot; similar phenomena were also observed in other catalytic systems [34,35]. On the other hand, at relatively high temperature (340–385°C), the detected NO x concentration at reactor outlet is obviously higher than that at reactor inlet, suggesting the decomposition of nitrate species; at this stage, the enhanced soot combustion should be simultaneously contributed by nitrates species and the NO2 species (the maximum: 797ppm) derived from the decomposition of nitrates. The NO2 as a stronger oxidizer than O2 can enhance soot combustion [36]. Actually, the exothermic soot combustion can reversely accelerate nitrate decomposition. From Fig. 10(b), it can be seen that as the soot co-exists with the catalyst the NO x release temperature is much lower and the detected maximal NO x concentration is much higher as compared with those measured in the absence of soot. This result further confirms that the nitrate decomposition facilitates the soot combustion and vise versa. Based upon all the results and analysis, a potential soot combustion mechanism with nitrate and NO2 as reaction intermediates is proposed for the CMALa10 in NO x -containing atmosphere, as shown in Fig. 11 . There are three kinetic pathways for soot combustion: (1) surface lattice oxygen species of the catalyst oxidize adjacent soot to produce CO2; (2) nitrate species stored on catalyst surface oxidize the soot, giving N2 and CO2; (3) soot is oxidized by the NO2 species derived from NO oxidation or nitrates decomposition. 4 Conclusions La-substituted hydrotalcite-derived Co2.5Mg0.5Al1–x%La x%O multiple-component oxide catalysts are highly active for soot combustion. The optimal substitution amount of La is x =10. This optimized catalyst CMALa10 possesses the largest specific surface area, the best reducibility and the highest NO x storage capacity. Finely dispersed Co3O4 is identified as the main active phase for soot combustion. La-substitution not only improves the reducibility of the catalysts but also increases the amount of surface lattice oxygen species. Above 200°C, NO x is mainly stored as chelating bidentate nitrate species, which can directly react with soot, remarkably decreasing the ignition temperature of soot combustion. The NO2 species derived from NO oxidation and nitrates decomposition can also enhance soot oxidation, remarkably decreasing the temperature T m corresponding to the maximal soot combustion rate. coredata.dc:description: A series of hydrotalcite-derived multicomponent oxide catalysts Co2.5Mg0.5Al1–x%La x%O (denoted as CMALa x , x =0, 5, 8, 10 or 15) with different La contents were synthesized by co-precipitation, and employed for catalytic soot combustion and NO x storage at lean condition. It is found that the La-substituted catalysts are more active than the one without La for soot combustion and NO x storage. Among all the catalysts CMALa x , CMALa10 (x =10) exhibits the highest catalytic performance, showing the largest NO x storage capacity (300μmol/g) and the lowest temperature for the maximal soot oxidation rate (T m =388°C). The results of H2-TPR and O2-TPD indicate that the La-substitution can enhance the redox properties and increase the amount of surface lattice oxygen species of the catalysts. The results of soot combustion kinetics show that the apparent activation energy of CMALa10 is the lowest (92.75kJ/mol). Based upon the catalytic performance and in situ DRIFTS characterization, a nitrate and/or NO2 enhanced soot combustion mechanism over CMALa10 was proposed. It is revealed that at low temperature the stored nitrate can directly promote soot ignition, while at high temperature the NO2 species arising from NO oxidation or nitrate decomposition act as the main active species for soot combustion.
coredata.dc:title: Enhanced soot combustion over partially substituted hydrotalcite-drived mixed oxide catalysts CoMgAlLaO
